Karl Barth was a Swiss theologian who lived from 1886 to 1968. He was a prominent figure in 20th century Protestant theology and wrote extensively on the relationship between language and theology.

Barth's view on the study of word meanings can be seen in his seminal work "Church Dogmatics" (1932-1967). Barth argued that language is central to the theological enterprise, as it is through language that we communicate our understanding of God and our relationship with God. He also believed that language is inherently limited and that we can never fully express the divine through words.

In particular, Barth emphasized the importance of the Word of God in Christian theology. He argued that the Word of God is not simply a set of words or propositions, but is a living, dynamic reality that speaks to us and transforms us. Barth believed that the Word of God is revealed to us through the Bible, but that our understanding of the Word is always limited by our finite human language and perspective.

Barth also critiqued the idea of using human reason to understand the divine. He argued that reason can never fully grasp the mysteries of God and that it is only through the revelation of the Word of God that we can come to know God.

One example of Barth's emphasis on the importance of language in theology can be seen in his discussion of the biblical concept of "grace." In "Church Dogmatics," Barth writes, "The word 'grace' is not a concept that can be grasped by the human mind, but a reality that is encountered and experienced by faith...The grace of God is not something that we can define or comprehend, but something that we can only receive through faith."

Another example of Barth's views on language and theology can be seen in his critique of natural theology. In "Church Dogmatics," Barth writes, "Theology cannot be based on natural reason or empirical observation, but must be based on the revelation of God in Jesus Christ. Any attempt to understand God apart from this revelation is doomed to failure."

Overall, Barth's view on the study of word meanings emphasizes the importance of language in theology and the limits of human language and reason when it comes to understanding the divine.
